author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Crummy economy can make you sick
text:
JB Reed/Bloomberg When unemployment goes up, so does the sale of Tums, Rolaids and Zantac, a study found. The lousy economy is giving people heartburn — literally.
A new Bloomberg Rankings study found the sale of acid reflux medications had a 93% correlation with the unemployment rate over the past five years.
When unemployment goes up, so does the sale of Tums, Rolaids and Zantac, the study found.
Drugs for high blood pressure had a similarly high correlation rate of 92%, and antidepressant sales tracked unemployment 85% of the time.
“The demand for drugs, especially in those classes, appears to be independent of major macroindicators, suggesting that people will find a way to pay for them,” said Andrew Berens of Bloomberg Industries.
“Especially the ones that alleviate anxiety, depression and maybe hypertension, which can be related to anxiety, too,” he said.
Unemployment is at 8.6% as of Nov. 30, down from a high of 10.2% in October 2009.
A separate study published in the medical journal Gut found a 50% jump in cases of acid reflux over 10 years in Norway, attributed to fattier diets.
About 20% of Americans suffer from acid reflux, according to the National Institutes of Health.
